segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 47
segments.en: Linked Discourses 47

segments.pli: 1. Ambapālivagga
segments.en: 1. In Ambapālī’s Wood

segments.pli: 10. Bhikkhunupassayasutta
segments.en: 10. The Nuns’ Quarters

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena aññataro bhikkhunupassayo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
segments.en: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the nuns’ quarters, and sat down on the seat spread out.

segments.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhuniyo yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho tā bhikkhuniyo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: Then several nuns went up to Venerable Ānanda bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

segments.pli: “Idha, bhante ānanda, sambahulā bhikkhuniyo catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā viharantiyo uḷāraṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ sañjānantī”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, Ānanda, several nuns meditate with their minds firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. They have realized a higher distinction than they had before.”

segments.pli: “Evametaṃ, bhaginiyo, evametaṃ, bhaginiyo.
segments.en: “That’s how it is, sisters! That’s how it is, sisters!

segments.pli: Yo hi koci, bhaginiyo, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto viharati, tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ:
segments.en: Any monk or nun who meditates with their mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation can expect to

segments.pli: ‘uḷāraṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ sañjānissatī’”ti.
segments.en: realize a higher distinction than they had before.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando tā bhikkhuniyo dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
segments.en: Then Ānanda educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired those nuns with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Ānanda wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

segments.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhante, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena aññataro bhikkhunupassayo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdiṃ.
Atha kho, bhante, sambahulā bhikkhuniyo yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho, bhante, tā bhikkhuniyo maṃ etadavocuṃ:
‘idha, bhante ānanda, sambahulā bhikkhuniyo catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā viharantiyo uḷāraṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ sañjānantī’ti.
Evaṃ vuttāhaṃ, bhante, tā bhikkhuniyo etadavocaṃ:
‘evametaṃ, bhaginiyo, evametaṃ, bhaginiyo.
Yo hi koci, bhaginiyo, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto viharati, tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—uḷāraṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ sañjānissatī’”ti.
“Evametaṃ, ānanda, evametaṃ, ānanda.
segments.en: “That’s so true, Ānanda! That’s so true!

segments.pli: Yo hi koci, ānanda, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto viharati, tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ:
segments.en: Any monk or nun who meditates with their mind firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation can expect to

segments.pli: ‘uḷāraṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ sañjānissati’.
segments.en: realize a higher distinction than they had before.

segments.pli: Katamesu catūsu?
segments.en: What four?

segments.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: Tassa kāye kāyānupassino viharato kāyārammaṇo vā uppajjati kāyasmiṃ pariḷāho, cetaso vā līnattaṃ, bahiddhā vā cittaṃ vikkhipati.
segments.en: As they meditate observing an aspect of the body, based on the body there arises physical tension, or mental sluggishness, or the mind is externally scattered.

segments.pli: Tenānanda, bhikkhunā kismiñcideva pasādanīye nimitte cittaṃ paṇidahitabbaṃ.
segments.en: That mendicant should direct their mind towards an inspiring foundation.

segments.pli: Tassa kismiñcideva pasādanīye nimitte cittaṃ paṇidahato pāmojjaṃ jāyati.
segments.en: As they do so, joy springs up.

segments.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati.
segments.en: Being joyful, rapture springs up.

segments.pli: Pītimanassa kāyo passambhati.
segments.en: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.

segments.pli: Passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vedayati.
segments.en: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.

segments.pli: Sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
segments.en: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

segments.pli: So iti paṭisañcikkhati:
segments.en: Then they reflect:

segments.pli: ‘yassa khvāhaṃ atthāya cittaṃ paṇidahiṃ, so me attho abhinipphanno.
segments.en: ‘I have accomplished the goal for which I directed my mind.

segments.pli: Handa dāni paṭisaṃharāmī’ti.
segments.en: Let me now pull back.’

segments.pli: So paṭisaṃharati ceva na ca vitakketi na ca vicāreti.
segments.en: They pull back, and neither place the mind nor keep it connected.

segments.pli: ‘Avitakkomhi avicāro, ajjhattaṃ satimā sukhamasmī’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: They understand: ‘I’m neither placing the mind nor keeping it connected. Mindful within myself, I’m happy.’

segments.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhu vedanāsu … pe …
segments.en: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of feelings …

segments.pli: citte … pe …
segments.en: mind …

segments.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
segments.en: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: Tassa dhammesu dhammānupassino viharato dhammārammaṇo vā uppajjati kāyasmiṃ pariḷāho, cetaso vā līnattaṃ, bahiddhā vā cittaṃ vikkhipati.
segments.en: As they meditate observing an aspect of principles, based on principles there arises physical tension, or mental sluggishness, or the mind is externally scattered.

segments.pli: Tenānanda, bhikkhunā kismiñcideva pasādanīye nimitte cittaṃ paṇidahitabbaṃ.
segments.en: That mendicant should direct their mind towards an inspiring foundation.

segments.en: As they do so, joy springs up.

segments.pli: Pamuditassa pīti jāyati.
segments.en: Being joyful, rapture springs up.

segments.en: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.

segments.en: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.

segments.pli: Sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyati.
segments.en: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

segments.pli: So iti paṭisañcikkhati:
segments.en: Then they reflect:

segments.pli: ‘yassa khvāhaṃ atthāya cittaṃ paṇidahiṃ, so me attho abhinipphanno.
segments.en: ‘I have accomplished the goal for which I directed my mind.

segments.pli: Handa dāni paṭisaṃharāmī’ti.
segments.en: Let me now pull back.’

segments.pli: So paṭisaṃharati ceva na ca vitakketi na ca vicāreti.
segments.en: They pull back, and neither place the mind nor keep it connected.

segments.pli: ‘Avitakkomhi avicāro, ajjhattaṃ satimā sukhamasmī’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: They understand: ‘I’m neither placing the mind nor keeping it connected. Mindful within myself, I’m happy.’

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, paṇidhāya bhāvanā hoti.
segments.en: That’s how there is directed development.

segments.pli: Kathañcānanda, appaṇidhāya bhāvanā hoti?
segments.en: And how is there undirected development?

segments.pli: Bahiddhā, ānanda, bhikkhu cittaṃ appaṇidhāya ‘appaṇihitaṃ me bahiddhā cittan’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: Not directing their mind externally, a mendicant understands: ‘My mind is not directed externally.’

segments.pli: Atha pacchāpure ‘asaṅkhittaṃ vimuttaṃ appaṇihitan’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: And they understand: ‘Over a period of time it’s unconstricted, freed, and undirected.’

segments.pli: Atha ca pana ‘kāye kāyānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā sukhamasmī’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: And they also understand: ‘I meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, mindful; I am happy.’

segments.pli: Bahiddhā, ānanda, bhikkhu cittaṃ appaṇidhāya ‘appaṇihitaṃ me bahiddhā cittan’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: Not directing their mind externally, a mendicant understands: ‘My mind is not directed externally.’

segments.pli: Atha pacchāpure ‘asaṅkhittaṃ vimuttaṃ appaṇihitan’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: And they understand: ‘Over a period of time it’s unconstricted, freed, and undirected.’

segments.pli: Atha ca pana ‘vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā sukhamasmī’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: And they also understand: ‘I meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, mindful; I am happy.’

segments.pli: Bahiddhā, ānanda, bhikkhu cittaṃ appaṇidhāya ‘appaṇihitaṃ me bahiddhā cittan’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: Not directing their mind externally, a mendicant understands: ‘My mind is not directed externally.’

segments.pli: Atha pacchāpure ‘asaṅkhittaṃ vimuttaṃ appaṇihitan’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: And they understand: ‘Over a period of time it’s unconstricted, freed, and undirected.’

segments.pli: Atha ca pana ‘citte cittānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā sukhamasmī’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: And they also understand: ‘I meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, mindful; I am happy.’

segments.pli: Bahiddhā, ānanda, bhikkhu cittaṃ appaṇidhāya ‘appaṇihitaṃ me bahiddhā cittan’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: Not directing their mind externally, a mendicant understands: ‘My mind is not directed externally.’

segments.pli: Atha pacchāpure ‘asaṅkhittaṃ vimuttaṃ appaṇihitan’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: And they understand: ‘Over a period of time it’s unconstricted, freed, and undirected.’

segments.pli: Atha ca pana ‘dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā sukhamasmī’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: And they also understand: ‘I meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, mindful; I am happy.’

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, appaṇidhāya bhāvanā hoti.
segments.en: That’s how there is undirected development.

segments.pli: Iti kho, ānanda, desitā mayā paṇidhāya bhāvanā, desitā appaṇidhāya bhāvanā.
segments.en: So, Ānanda, I’ve taught you directed development and undirected development.

segments.pli: Yaṃ, ānanda, satthārā karaṇīyaṃ sāvakānaṃ hitesinā anukampakena anukampaṃ upādāya, kataṃ vo taṃ mayā.
segments.en: Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.

segments.pli: Etāni, ānanda, rukkhamūlāni, etāni suññāgārāni. Jhāyathānanda, mā pamādattha; mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha. Ayaṃ vo amhākaṃ anusāsanī”ti.
segments.en: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”

segments.pli: Idamavoca bhagavā.
segments.en: That is what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
segments.en: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Dasamaṃ.
Ambapālivaggo paṭhamo.
Ambapāli sato bhikkhu,
Sālā kusalarāsi ca;
Sakuṇagghi makkaṭo sūdo,
Gilāno bhikkhunupassayoti.

suttaplex.blurb: When Ānanda visits the nuns’s quarters they tell him that their meditation is prospering to higher and higher levels. Ānanda reporrts the good news to the Buddha, who speaks of two ways of developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation: directed and undirected.
